questions.text: A 2year old child with a long history of purulent nasal discharge now presents with fever and right sided conjunctival congestion and edema for past 3 days. See picture given below. His fever is 103 F and WBC count is 12000/ ul. The culture of eye discharge was negative. Xray shows opacification of ethmoid sinus. Which of the following should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
The child shown in the above picture has probably developed orbital cellulitis or orbital abscess following ethmoid sinusitis  for which a CT scan should be done first.

CT scan will differentiate orbital cellulitis from orbital abscess and helps to see the extent of involvement of sinuses.

In this case of orbital cellulitis after initial stabilization with antibiotics, FESS should be performed later on for chronic sinusitis. If orbital abscess is there it will require antibiotics along orbital decompression and FESS.

The most common Acute complication of sinusitis are  orbital complications. Orbital complication occurs most commonly following ethmoid sinusitis.

Ethmoid sinus is seperated from the orbit only by a thin bone known as lamina papyracea Also the venous supply of orbit and ethmoid sinus are the same.

The orbital complications are as follows:

Periorbital oedema : it involves only the preseptal space. Vision is normal.

Orbital cellulitis: it involves conjunctival chemosis, proptosis, restricted ocular movements partial or Total loss of vision.

Orbital abscess and cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A: In this case of orbital cellulitis after initial stabilization with antibiotics, FESS should be performed later on for chronic sinusitis. If orbital abscess is there it will require antibiotics along orbital decompression and FESS.

Option C: Blood culture can be used in management however CT scan for Differentiating Cellulitis and Abscess is Priority.

Option D: culture of eye discharge may be required later in Orbital abscess in Culturing microorganism and choosing antibiotics. But in question it’s already given a negative so no role of repeating the test.

Chandler Grading:

Key Takeaway:

CT scan is useful in differentiating orbital cellulitis from orbital abscess and helps to see the extent of involvement of sinuses.

choices.text: Local debridement and IV amphotericin B

questions.text: A Type 1 diabetic patient presents with fever, left sided facial oedema, periodontal oedema, diplopia, and acidosis breath. On examination, there were necrotic areas on the upper lip, black necrotic mass in the nasal cavity, as shown in the picture below. She should be managed by-
questions.solution:
Detailed Explanation: Based on clinical findings and endoscopic picture, it is a case of Mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is a type of invasive fungal infection. It is caused by Mucor and Rhizopus.

The fungus invades the blood vessels angio-invasive and spreads rapidly through the nose and sinuses to orbit and intracranially.

On examination, black necrotic turbinates and debris is seen. CT scan shows bony erosion and tissue infiltration.

It is a life threatening condition, it should be managed by Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of all the involved tissue.

If orbit is involved, orbital exenteration should be done. Reversal of underlying cause of immunosuppression.

Option A: As mucor is angioinvasive, surgical debridement with Amphotericin B is required on urgent basis.

Option C: Cisplatin has no role in managing Mucormycosis

Option D: Steroid may worsen underlying immunosuppression.

Key Takeaway: Mucormycosis, an opportunistic infection caused by rhizopus and mucor mainly occurring in DM and immunocompromised patients should be urgently looked for. Managements include local debridement with IV Amphotericin B. Local tissue culture is useful in identifying fungus.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with history of nasal blockage for 6 months. On examination the patient had a nasal mass with mucinous discharge. The CT scan is showing double density sign. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan given below?
questions.solution:
The CT scan picture shown above shows haziness of the maxillary sinus and mass in the left nasal cavity without any bony erosion.

The CT scan also shows heterogeneous density in the mass known as double density sign. This is characteristic of Allergic fungal rhinitis.

Bent and Kuhn criteria of Allergic fungal rhinitis are.

  • Type 1 hypersensitivity is raised.
  • Nasal polyps, positive fungal stain.
  • Biopsy showing fungal elements, allergic mucin.
  • CT showing hazy sinus with heterogeneous appearance.

Option A: Antrochoanal polyp presents as a unilateral nasal mass which is purulent in nature and not mucinous.

Option B: Maxillary carcinoma will show bony erosion in CT scan.

Option D: Angiofibroma Presents in Adolescent with Recurrent epistaxis. On CT scan shows Holman miller sign pushing posterior wall of Maxillary antrum.

Key Takeaway:

Haziness of Maxillary sinus without bony erosion and Double density signs are characteristic of Allergic Fungal Sinusitis.

Image reference: Radiopedia website.

choices.text: Proliferative aspergillosis of the frontal sinus
Osteomyelitis of frontal bone causing subperiosteal abscess

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient known case of chronic rhino sinusitis presented with a complain of painful, firm swelling at the forehead region. Picture Is given below. Patient is also a known case of diabetes mellitus. What is the pathology involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and history the most probable diagnosis in this case will be Pott's puffy tumor.

Pott's puffy tumor is not an actual tumor. It is an osteomyelitis of the frontal bone which later on leads to abscess formation in the subperiosteal plane.

It affects the anterior table of the frontal bone. It is mainly seen in adults and in immunocompromised states.

The abscess presents as a soft doughy swelling over the forehead.  

Management includes broad spectrum antibiotics along with surgical drainage of the abscess and the necrosed bone.

Option A: Osteosarcoma is aggressive Malignant Tumor with bony destruction and Hard in consistency.

Option B: Aspergillosis a fungal infection involves sinus and shows sinus walls thickening and double density sign.

Option D: Fibrous Dysplasia due to excessive bone growth present with facial deformities unlike abscess.

Key Takeaway: Pott's puffy tumor is soft doughy swelling over the forehead. It is an osteomyelitis of the anterior table of frontal bone which later on leads to abscess formation in the subperiosteal plane in Immunocompromised adults.

Image reference: www.drganent.com

questions.text: A 45 year old female known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis presents with a firm , non tender swelling in the superomedial quadrant of orbit pushing orbit downwards and laterally. Patient has swelling since 2 months. Picture given below. What is the most common diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patient is a known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis so this condition is a complication of it.

Patient has swelling since 2 months which indicates it is a chronic complication. The swelling is non tender thus it is of non inflammatory in nature. Based on these facts probable diagnosis of frontal sinus Mucocele is made.

Mucocele occurs because of chronic obstruction of ostia of sinuses or cystic dilatation of mucous glands of sinus.

The most common site of formation of mucocele is frontal sinus. The mucocele of frontal sinus pushes the orbit downwards and laterally. Mucocele of ethmoid sinus pushes orbit forwards and laterally.

Option A: Pott's puffy tumor is soft doughy swelling over the forehead. It is an osteomyelitis of the anterior table of  frontal bone which later on leads to abscess formation in the subperiosteal plane in Immunocompromised adults. So it’s inflammatory condition.

Option C: orbital cellulitis is acute inflammatory complication of sinusitis and present with fever localised edema vision changes like features.

Option D: Subperiosteal abscess is tender swelling caused by pus collection between medial periosteum and lamina papyracea with impaired extraocular movement.

Key Takeaway: Frontal sinus mucocele is non tender non inflammatory chronic complications of sinusitis. It occurs due to cystic dilation of mucous glands of sinus

Image reference: The Permanente journal.

choices.text: It also presents with lateral gaze palsy involving lateral rectus muscle
It occurs because of dilatation of mucous glands of sinuses
It is a subperiosteal abscess involving frontal sinus
Periorbital oedema and conjunctival chemosis may develop.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient presented with complain of soft doughy and inflamed swelling on the forehead. Picture given below. Patient is known case of diabetes and he is also a known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Patient is a known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis. The swelling is soft, doughy and inflamed. The diagnosis in this case is Potts puffy tumour.

Osteomyelitis following frontal sinusitis affects inly the anterior table of the frontal bone since presence of marrow is limited to the anterior table. It is seen mainly in adults since frontal sinus is not fully developed in childrens.

The subperiosteal abscess following Osteomyelitis of frontal bone presents externally as a soft doughy swelling known as Potts puffy tumour.

Management includes Surgical drainage of the abscess and removal of necrotic bone after elevating the perichondrium of frontal sinus.

Option A & D: Lateral gaze palsy, periorbital edema, conjunctival chemosis are the features of cavernous sinus thrombosis hence these options were wrong.

Option C: Dilatation of mucous glands of sinuses is seen in Mucocele.

Key Takeaway: Pott's puffy tumor is soft doughy swelling over the forehead. It is an osteomyelitis of the anterior table of frontal bone which later on leads to abscess formation in the subperiosteal plane in Immunocompromised adults.

Image reference: www.omicsonline.org

choices.text: Periorbital edema is the earliest finding

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis presents with Acute onset of conjunctival chemosis, proptosis and fever. Provisional diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis was made. Which of the following is not a feature of cavernous sinus thrombosis?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic nerve plexus present surrounding the internal carotid artery are stimulated in the cavernous sinus thrombosis thus option B is wrong.

The main differential diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis is orbital cellulitis. No involvement of sympathetic plexus is seen in orbital cellulitis.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 55 year female patient known case of chronic sinusitis with type 2 diabetes presented with complain of acute onset bilateral conjunctival chemosis, bilateral proptosis and fever. Picture Is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis can occur due to infection following any part of the dangerous area of face (via deep facial vein and pterygoid plexus) and infection in the ethmoid sinus (via orbit and orbital vessels).

Clinical features : The patient presents abruptly with fever with chills and rigors. Eye swelling begins unilaterally than spreads bilaterally within 24 to 48 hours. Periodontal oedema is the earliest findings. Conjunctival chemosis occurs.

Lateral gaze palsy due to isolated cranial nerve 6 palsy. Ptosis and mydriasis occurs, sympathetic plexus becomes activated and pupils becomes further dilated and fixed.

Option A: Lateral sinus Thrombosis present with tender shined out mastoid known as griesinger sign.

Option B: Frontal sinus abscess is tender swelling present with fever congestion localised edema features.

Option D: meningitis presents with Meninges irritation like brudzinski and kernig signs with nuchal rigidity and back pain.

Key Takeaway: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is abrupt onset initial Unilateral swelling become bilateral within 24-48 hours. From earliest Periodontal edema and conjunctival chemosis to lateral gaze palsy and sympathetic system stimulation occurs later.

Image reference: journals.iww.com

questions.text: A 60 year old female patient presented with complain of swelling over right cheek and diplopia. On nasal endoscopy a mass was seen from right maxillary sinus opening. Biopsy was taken which shows squamous cell carcinoma. CT PNS was performed which shows Mass in right maxillary sinus with erosion of bone of posterior wall of maxillary sinus, pterygoid plates, superior wall of sinus extending anteriorly into subcutaneous tissue and skin of the cheek. What will be the T staging in this case as per TNM staging?
questions.solution:
T staging in TNM classification of malignant tumors of maxillary sinus is as follows:

Key Takeaway:

T1: No Bone Erosion

T2: Erosion / Medial and Inferior wall of sinus

T3: Posterior wall Pterygoid fossa Ethmoid Sinus

T4 a: Sphenoid and Frontal sinus / Pterygoid plate / Infratemporal fossa / Cribriform plate

T4 b: Remaining Intracranial Structures.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presented with nasal polyps. Endoscopy picture is given below. He has also developed Bronchiectesis, He is not able to become a father even after 5 years of marriage. What is the most probable syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
Allergic rhinitis leads to nasal polyps, many patients having allergic rhinitis also have asthma if nasal polyps and asthma are associated with aspirin hypersensitivity then it is called Samter s triad.

Option B: Young s syndrome is associated with sinusitis, Bronchiectesis and azoospermia leading to infertility

Option C: Kartagener s syndrome is associated with sinusitis, Bronchiectasis and situs inversus.

Option D: Dodd Sign is seen in nasal polyp.

Key Takeaway:

Samter triad = Nasal polyp + Asthma + Aspirin Hypersensitivity.

Image reference: fort worth ent website.

questions.text: A 25 year male patient presented with complain of immobile swelling over the cheek region since 2 months. Nasal endoscopy was performed was found to be normal. CT PNS showed presence of mass in left maxillary sinus. The mass has ground glass appearance on CT. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and CT scan findings the probable diagnosis in this case is Fibrous dysplasia.

This is an idiopathic benign tumour where medullary bone is replaced by poorly organized fibro-osseous tissue.

Most common site of involvement is maxilla. It presents as an asymmetrical painless enlargement of one side of cheek.

The Fibrous tissue expands to fill the maxillary sinus also. It is more commonly seen in young age.

CT scan is the investigation of choice. CT scan shows çharacterstic ground glass appearance. Management is by surgical Resection and repair of maxillary bone.

Option A: mucocele is non tender non inflammatory chronic complications of sinusitis. It occurs due to cystic dilation of mucous glands of sinus.

Option B: Osteoma is benign bone growth which are hard and lobukated with ivory like appearance often mixed with coarse granular component.

Option D: Inverted papilloma/Schneiderian/Ringertz Tumor is MC benign tumour of nasal cavity. It’s Premalignant, recurrent, locally invasive, arises lateral wall of nose. It shows papillary appearance on histology. No role of radiotherapy, rx is with wide excision.

Key Takeaway: Fibrous dysplasia benign bone Tumor present with asymmetric painless enlargement in maxilla. In CT Scan shows ground glass appearance and managed with surgical excision.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: Clear periorbital with preservation of orbital contents
Resect the periorbital and orbital fat under microscopic control for negative margins

questions.text: A 45 year male patient known case of squamous cell carcinoma of paranasal sinus. His CT Scan was done which shows invasion of orbit. The tumour was invading extra-ocular muscles and orbital Apex. CT scan picture given below. What will be the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Management Guideline Depend on Lamina Papyrcea and EOM Involvement.

Key Takeaway: When SCC Of Sinus involves Extra Ocular muscle or orbital apex it’s managed with orbital Extenteration.

Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient known case of squamous cell carcinoma of paranasal sinus. His CT Scan was performed. CT scan shows tumor extending from ethmoid sinus to medial wall of orbit and maxillary sinus. What will be the T staging in this case?
questions.solution:
Tis (carcinoma in situ) means the tumour is in the top layer of cells that line the inside of the ethmoid sinus and has not grown deeper.

T1 means the tumour is only in one part of the ethmoid sinus, but it may have grown into the bones of the sinus

T2 means the tumour has grown into other parts of the ethmoid sinus, or into both the nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus. It may have grown into the bones of the nasal cavity or ethmoid sinus.

T3 means the tumour has spread into the side or bottom of the eye socket, the maxillary sinus, the roof of the mouth (palate) or the bone that separates the nose from the brain (cribriform plate).

T4a means the tumour has spread into the:

  • front part of the eye socket
  • skin of the nose or cheek
  • sphenoid or frontal sinuses, or bones in the face (pterygoid plates)

This is also called moderately advanced local disease.

T4b means the tumour has spread into the:

  • back part of the eye socket
  • brain
  • layer of tissue covering the brain (dura)
  • parts of the skull
  • some of the nerves that connect the brain to the body (cranial nerves), or the area connecting the back of the nose to the back of the mouth (nasopharynx)

This is also known as very advanced local disease.

Key Takeaway:

T1: No Bone Erosion

T2: Erosion / Medial and Inferior wall of sinus

T3: Posterior wall of maxilary sinus Pterygoid fossa Ethmoid Sinus

T4 a: Sphenoid and Frontal sinus / Pterygoid plate / Infratemporal fossa / Cribriform plate

T4 b: Remaining Intracranial Structures.

Image reference: Science photo library.

questions.text: A 55 year male patient presented with complain of nasal obstruction and intermittent nasal bleeding. On examination a mass was seen arising from Lateral wall of nose. Biopsy was taken. Histopathology report suggested presence of stratified columnar epithelium admired with mucin containing cells and numerous micro cysts. Picture given below. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopically papillomas are composed of proliferating columnar and or squamous epithelial cells with an admixture of mucin containing cells with numerous micro cysts.

Sino nasal papilloma are benign neoplasm of respiratory mucosa. The ectodermally derived schneiderian membrane.

They give rise to three distinct patterns: inverted, oncocytic and exophytic papilloma collectively known as Schneiderian papiloma.

Option A : B cell lymphoma presents as a large cell lymphoma with a diffuse pattern of growth.

Option C : Haemangiopericytoma is a vascular tumour in nasal cavity or paranasal sinus.

Option D : Rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the common malignancy of nasopharynx in childrens.

Key Takeaway:

Inverted papilloma/Schneiderian/Ringertz Tumor is  MC benign tumour of nasal cavity. It’s Premalignant, recurrent, locally invasive, arises lateral wall of nose. It shows stratified columnar epithelium admired with mucin containing cells and numerous micro cysts on histology. No role of radiotherapy, rx is with wide excision.

questions.text: A 40 year male patient presented with complain of headache, diplopia and facial deformity. His CT Scan was performed which shows presence of dense well circumscribed mass. Mass was excised. Histology shows dense bone lacking harversian system. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is frontal sinus Osteoma.

It is the most common benign tumor of paranasal sinus. Osteoma are osteogenic tumor composed of mature bone.

It is most commonly seen in frontal sinus followed by ethmoid sinus, maxillary and sphenoid sinus.

Clinical features it causes mass effect leading to headache, diplopia and facial deformity. It can lead to obstruction of ostia leading to chronic sinusitis and Mucocele.

Radiological appearance is that of dense circumscribed mass.

Histopathology shows dense bone lacking harversian system. It can be associated with soft tissue tumors and intestinal polyposis.

Management is removal of frontal and ethmoidal Osteoma is by external  fronto- ethmoidectomy. This is known as Lynch Howarth approach.

Option A : Fibrous dysplasia benign bone Tumor present with asymmetric painless enlargement in maxilla. In CT Scan shows ground glass appearance and managed with surgical excision.

Option B : Olfactory neuroblastoma Being highly vascular Tumor present like cherry red polypoidal mass in nasal mucosa.

Option D : Inverted papilloma/Schneiderian/Ringertz Tumor is MC benign tumour of nasal cavity. It’s Premalignant, recurrent, locally invasive, arises from lateral wall of nose. It shows stratified columnar epithelium admired with mucin containing cells and numerous micro cysts on histology. No role of radiotherapy, rx is with wide excision.

Key Takeaway:

Osteoma Benign bone Tumor lacking Haversian system present with Diplopia and facial deformities. Managed with external frontoethmoidectomy by lynch Howarth incision.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: Commonest site of CSF leak is lateral lamellar of cribriform plate
Beta 2 transferring estimation is highly specific for diagnosis
Fluorescein dye can be used intrathecally for diagnosis of site of leak
MRI gadolinium enhanced T1 images are best for diagnosis of site active leak

questions.text: A 25 year old male sports player got hit on face. He developed complain of unilateral nasal discharge. He is not able to sniff back the nasal discharge. The discharge does not stiffen on the handkerchief. All of the following statements are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Test used to differentiate CSF rhinorrhoea and rhinitis rhinorrhoea are sniff test, reservoir sign , handkerchief test, jugular vein compression.

Test used to differentiate csf leak vs epistaxis Halo sign/ target sign

Diagnostic biochemical test for csf leak is beta 2 transferrin. ( Option B )

Diagnostic radiological test for active leak is CT cisternography of base of skull. ( Option D ). Fluorescent dye can also be used for diagnosis of leak ( Option C )

Commonest site : Lateral lamella of cribriform plate ( Option A )

Treatment is initial conservative management for 2 weeks. If no benefit than endoscopic repair.

Key Takeaway:

CSF Rhinorrhea Diagnostic Tests for active leak :

Biochemical - Beta 2 Transferrin

Radiological - CT Cisternography

choices.text: Closed reduction of nasal bone fracture

questions.text: The following instruments are used in which surgery?
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the above image are

a) elevator b) walsham forceps c) ash s forceps.

The above given three instruments are used in closed reduction and fixation of nasal bone fracture.

Walsham forceps are used for reduction of nasal bone. Mnemonic - wall are strong like bone

Ash s forceps is used for reduction of septum. Mnemonic A s h for s eptum.

Option B: FESS Requires different sized endoscopes.

Option C: Nasal Packing done by Tilleys Forceps

Option D: Polypectomy done by Snare Forceps.

Key Takeaway:

Forceps in ENT

Walsham - Nasal bone Fracture

Ash - Nasal septum Fracture

Image reference: ENT UK.com

questions.text: A 25 year male patient developed injury over face due to road traffic accident. A 3d CT scan of face was advised. The CT scan shows presence of fracture in the maxilla. The fracture line was passing through the upper border of nasal bone extending to superior orbital fissure going posteriorly towards zygoma. What will be the grading of this fracture as per Le fort classification?
questions.solution:
The maxillary fractures are high velocity fractures. They are of 3 types

Le fort 1 The fracture runs parallel to the palate. The fracture line passes from the lower part of maxillary antrum and floor of nose anteriorly to pterygoid plates posteriorly.

Le fort 2 this is a pyramidal fracture the fracture line runs on both side from floor of maxillary sinus going superiorly to infra orbital margin zygoma. Lacrimal bone, nasal bone and Nasion .

Le fort 3 this leads to craniotomy facial dysfunction. It starts from Nasion to superior orbital fissure and extending posteriorly to zygoma and skull base. It leads to csf rhinorrhoea.

There is no Le fort 4 Fracture. ( Option D )

Key Takeaway:

Le Fort 1 - Hanging Palate / Floating Tooth

Le fort 2 - Hanging Maxilla

Le Fort 3 - Craniofacial Disjunction

Image reference: science photo library.

choices.text: Wait for 2 weeks for spontaneous stoppage of leakage
Immediate cisternography and transcranial surgery to close the defect
Endoscopic surgery to stop the leakage

questions.text: A 25 year patient known case of head injury developed complain of unilateral nasal discharge following injury. His CT Scan was done which was suggestive of CSF leak through cribriform plate. Picture given below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Any disruption in the bone, dura and arachnoid matter of the base of skull can lead to exit of CSF from subarachnoid space to the nose.

Etiology: 95% is traumatic and 5% is nontraumatic.

Clinical features unilateral nasal discharge increasing on leaning forwards, various bedside test are used for diagnosis such as sniff test, handkerchief test, target sign, reservoir sign.

Biochemical test : Glucose estimation and beta 2 transferrin.

HRCT is done to visualize fracture sites in skull base. Localities test are intrathecal dye administration and Ct cisternography.

Management: For traumatic cases conservative management has to be followed initially for 10 to 14 days it includes Bed rest in propped up position ( Option A ) , Diuretics, avoidance of straining, prophylactic antibiotics.

If the patient does not benefit from medical management, surgical repair either endoscopic or external is done. ( Option C & D )

Key Takeaway:

Majorities of CSF Leak improves with Initial conservative treatment for 2 Weeks. If Patient does not benefit then only Endoscopic / External drainage is done.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: It's management includes open reduction and internal filtration if displaced
It occurs at the junction of three bones frontal, temporal and maxilla
Most commonly injured nerve is the Infra orbital nerve

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient presented with complain of swelling over cheek region following an accident. On examination there was flattening of malar eminence and trismus. 3 D CT scan of face revealed tripod fracture. Picture given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
The other name of the zygomatic fracture is the tripod fracture. It develops at the junction between the three bones : Frontal, maxillary and temporal. (Option B) It leads to Exophthalmos and not Exophthalmos. ( Option D )

It is the 2nd most common fracture of the facial skeleton. It’s clinical features includes: Flattening of the malar eminence, Trismus due to zygoma impinging on coronoid process of mandible. Anaesthesia over territory of Infra orbital nerve. (Option C)

Orbital findings includes : periorbital emphysema, step deformity of infraorbital margin, restricted ocular movements and diplopia, Enophthalmos. (Option D)

Management includes open reduction and internal filtration if displaced by using wire. (Option A)

Key Takeaway: Tripod Fracture Involves Frontal Maxilla & Zygomatic bone fracture. It leads to infraorbital nerve injury so flattening of Malar prominence & Enophthalmos due to Restricted ocular movements.

Image reference: Research gate.

choices.text: He should be taken up for open reduction one week later
He should be taken for closed reduction as soon as overlying oedema subsides
Septoplasty should be done in the same sitting
He should be kept under observation

questions.text: An 18 year old male patient was hit on the nose while playing football. He developed external deformity of nose. His Xray nose lateral view shows displaced nasal bone fracture. Which of the following is true about this condition ?
questions.solution:
Nasal bone fracture is one of the most common fractures involving the facial skeleton.

3 things needs to be evaluated in this case: Nasal bone deformity, septal deviation and septal hematoma.

Clinical features includes pain and oedema at and surrounding the nose, intermittent nasal bleeding, external deformity of the nose.

There are three types of fractures: class1 vertical fractures, class 2 horizontal fractures, class 3 naso-orbito- ethmoidal fractures.

Management: The management of class 1 and class 2 fractures is closed reduction ( Option A ) of nasal bone fracture after the overlying oedema subsides. The ideal time for fracture reduction is 1 week after the injury.

In closed reduction two types of forceps are used Ash s and walsham s forceps. If significant septal deformity exist even after closes reduction than septoplasty can be done in the same sitting if patient is more than 17 years.

In case of late presentation after 3 weeks of injury open reduction rhinoplasty is performed.  ( Option C )

Simple observation doesn’t suffice as risk of Septal haematoma and perforation ( Option D )

Key Takeaway:

Management of Class 1 & 2 Fractures :

  • Timing of Presentation:
    • Within 5-7 Days: If edema subsides:
      • No Deformity: Symptomatic treatment.
      • Deformity Present: Closed reduction.
    • After 3 Weeks (Callous Formation): Open reduction:
      • Rhinoplasty/Septo-rhinoplasty.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 19 year old male patient presented with complain of swelling over left side cheek region, on examination there was flattening of malar eminence. Xray is suggestive of fracture of zygoma. Which nerve is most commonly damage in this fracture?
questions.solution:
Most common nerve injured during the zygomatic fracture is the Infra orbital nerve.

The maxillary Nerve exits the orbit through the Infra orbital foramen below the Infra orbital nerve. It is prone to injury here.

Zygomatic fracture is the 2nd most common fracture of the face. Clinical features includes flattening of malar eminence, Trismus, anaesthesia in the territory of Infra orbital nerve.

Orbital findings includes: periorbital emphysema, step deformity of Infra orbital margin, restricted ocular movements and enopthalmos.

Management includes If fracture is undisputed nothing has to be done. If displaced these fracture have to be reduced by open reduction and internal wire fixation.

Key Takeaway:

Tripod Fracture Involves Frontal Maxilla & Zygomatic bone fracture. It leads to infraorbital nerve injury so flattening of Malar prominence & Enophthalmos due to Restricted ocular movements.

Image reference: Radiopedia.
